oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Malignant catarrhal fever: Foreign Animal Diseases

Foreign Animal Diseases
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Malignant catarrhal fever (MCF), also known as bovine malignant catarrh or snotsiekte, is an acute, usually fatal, generalized in disease of cattle and several species of wild ruminants. The disease is characterized by fever, catarrhal rhinitis and conjunctivitis, enlarged lymph nodes, and mortality of nearly 100 percent. The causative agent of at least one form of MCF is a herpesvirus. The disease is worldwide in its distribution, but it is sporadic in its occurence.
